qas.question: What draws together the axes of cultural and social anthropology?
What studies the way people make sense of the world around them?
Which type of anthropology studies relationships among persons and groups?
What does social anthropology help develop an understanding of?
What kind of distinction is lacking between social and cultural anthropology?
What draws together the aces of Sociocultural anthropology?
What studies how people use the world around them?
What type of anthropology studies relationships among persons and their history?
What type off anthropology has a hard-and-fast distinction from social anthropology?

context: <a0_0>Sociocultural anthropology<a0_0/> draws together the principle axes of <b5_0>cultural anthropology and social anthropology<b5_0/>. <a1_0>Cultural anthropology<a1_0/> is the comparative study of the manifold ways in which people make sense of the world around them, while <a2_0>social<a2_0/> anthropology is the study of the relationships among persons and groups. <b6_0><b8_0>Cultural anthropology<b8_0/><b6_0/> is more related to philosophy, literature and the arts (how one's culture affects experience for self and group, contributing to more complete understanding of the people's knowledge, customs, and institutions), while <b7_0>social<b7_0/> anthropology is more related to sociology and history. in that it helps develop understanding of <a3_0>social structures,<a3_0/> typically of others and other populations (such as minorities, subgroups, dissidents, etc.). There is no <a4_0>hard-and-fast<a4_0/> distinction between them, and these categories overlap to a considerable degree.
